name.text: Reaction Forces and Free Body Diagram - Kg. Level 1.Question ID #1

questiontext.text:
A simply supported beam of length 97 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two supports, one at either end of the beam, hence reactions forces R1 and R2. There is a point mass of 10 kg acting at a distance 53 cm from point A.

You may assume a value of g of 10 m/s2.

Calculate the values of R1 and R2, giving your answers to 2 d.p.

R1: {1:NUMERICAL:=45.36:0.4536#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N
R2: {1:NUMERICAL:=54.64:0.5464#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N

generalfeedback.text:
When a system is in equilibrium the total forces and the total moment need to be equal to zero; otherwise the system will be moving or rotating, respectively.

Use the convention that upward forces and anti-clockwise moments are positive, as shown in the diagram below.

In this case taking moments about A, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Mz=0 $$\rightarrow$$ (0.97m x R2) - (0.53m x 100N) = 0

Hence:

R2 = 54.64N.


In this case resolving vertical forces, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Fy=0 $$\rightarrow$$ R1 + R2 - 100 = 0.

Hence:

R1 = 45.36N.


The equation $$\small\sum$$ Fx=0 still holds true in this case, but is not used here as there are no forces with an x-component.

hint.text:
HINT

For a system to be in equilibirum, total forces in both x and y directions must be balanced.

Also, for a system to be in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

generalfeedback.text:
When a system is in equilibrium the total forces and the total moment need to be equal to zero; otherwise the system will be moving or rotating, respectively.

Use the convention that upward forces and anti-clockwise moments are positive, as shown in the diagram below.

In this case taking moments about A, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Mz=0 $$\rightarrow$$ (0.91m x R2) - (0.52m x 90N) = 0

Hence:

R2 = 51.43N.


In this case resolving vertical forces, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Fy=0 $$\rightarrow$$ R1 + R2 - 90 = 0.

Hence:

R1 = 38.57N.


The equation $$\small\sum$$ Fx=0 still holds true in this case, but is not used here as there are no forces with an x-component.

hint.text:
HINT

For a system to be in equilibirum, total forces in both x and y directions must be balanced.

Also, for a system to be in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.
